data: By and large, New York City is the heart of this country's [the United States'] literary establishment.

Not only is the city the location of influential book reviews (most notably The New York Times Book Review and The New York Review of Books), influential magazines such as The New Yorker, Time, and Newsweek, and many influential book publishers, the city also boasts a large and lively population of literary writers and readers.
For the last century, this unique combination has made New York the country's literary hub.
If a novel isn't successful with the New York establishment, it rarely has a chance of entering this country's literary canon.
But how does Physarum, a single-celled amoeba-like organism, make decisions without a brain? The answer is deceptively simple – it does so by committee.
Every plasmodium (a single cell with many nuclei) is basically a big sac of fluid, where each part rhythmically contracts and expands, pushing the fluid inside back-and-forth.
The rate of the contractions depends on what neighbouring parts of the sac are doing, and on the local environment.
They happen faster when the plasmodium touches something attractive like food, and they slow down when repellent things like sunlight are nearby.
Despite being a single cell, each part of the plasmodium acts like a tiny individual, reacting to information from its environment.
By combining these reactions, the entire plasmodium flows towards things it likes and away from things it doesn’t, all without a single conscious thought.
It’s the ultimate in collective decision-making and it allows Physarum to perform remarkable feats of “intelligence”.
The UK is rated fairly highly – 14th out of 50 - in the Nation Brands Index for the quality of the welcome would-be visitors believe they will get when they come here.
But some of our key competitors such as Canada, Italy, Spain and the Netherlands do better.
The VisitBritain research shows foreign visitors often find Britain’s mix of cutting-edge modernity and rich cultural heritage "fascinating" and "exciting".
They see British people as "honest", "funny", "kind" and "efficient" but in some cases they wish we offered a more exuberant welcome.
In choosing a partner we try both to retain the relationships we have enjoyed in childhood, and to recoup ourselves for fantasies which have been denied us.

Mate-selection accordingly becomes for many an attempt to cast a particular part in a fantasy production of their own, and since both parties have the same intention but rarely quite the same fantasies, the result may well be a duel of rival producers.
There are men, as Stanley Spencer said of himself, who need two complementary wives, and women who need two complementary husbands, or at least two complementary love objects.
“Also in 1895, American inventor Major Woodville Latham developed an unpopular projector called an Eidoloscope (or Panoptikon projector).
What was most innovative was its Latham Loop, the addition of a slack-forming loop to the film path to restrain the inertia of the take-up reel, and prevent the tearing of sprocket holes.
It also allowed for the use of films longer than three minutes.
(The loop is still used in virtually all film cameras and projectors to this day.)”
In 2009, immigrants — be they legal or unauthorized — comprised 12.8% of the total population of the United States and 15.7% of the total adult population.
However, because of their youthful age structure and higher fertility rates, immigrant adults are more likely than native-born adults to be parents of children younger than 18.
As a result, they are the parents of 23% of all children in this country ages 17 and younger.
About 85% of these children of immigrants were born in the United States.
Unauthorized immigrant adults, in particular, skew young.
The median age of all U.S.-born adults (ages 18 and older) in 2009 was 46.3 years.
For legal immigrants, this figure was 45.9; for unauthorized immigrants, it was more than a decade younger—35.5, according to the Pew Hispanic estimates.
Most immigrants come to the United States as children.

Escalators do offer some big opportunities for energy-saving if you can figure out how to cut power consumption during those periods when they chug along without any passengers.
Option 1 is to slow down the escalator when it's empty, essentially putting it into sleep mode.

These "intermittent" or "variable-speed" escalators are popular in Europe and Asia, but haven't gained much traction in the United States, thanks to a recommended national safety code that advises against escalators changing speed.

(The forthcoming update to the code will lift that injunction for new machines.) The actual savings on a given escalator will depend on how often the unit is idle, but a recent European study estimated that installing variable-speed drives on all the region's escalators could reduce total electricity use by about 28 percent.
Across 4 studies, the authors found that participants scoring in the bottom quartile on tests of humor, grammar, and logic grossly overestimated their test performance and ability.
Although their test scores put them in the 12th percentile, they estimated themselves to be in the 62nd.
Several analyses linked this miscalibration to deficits in metacognitive skill, or the capacity to distinguish accuracy from error.
Paradoxically, improving the skills of participants, and thus increasing their metacognitive competence, helped them recognize the limitations of their abilities.

The research compared the book markets in the UK (with a strong copyright law) and Germany (with either weak or non-existent copyright), and found much more writing going on in Germany and (more importantly) much more innovation in the bookselling market.
In the UK, where copyright limited printings, books were expensive and only owned by the wealthy and elite.

In Germany, where copyright was weak or didn't exist, certainly there was a fair amount of copying of other books, but it resulted in widespread innovation in the book market, including segmenting the market into hardcovers (for the wealthy and the elite) and the introduction of cheaper paperbacks for those less well off.
Not only that, but the sorts of works created again favor the lack of copyright.

While writing in the UK tended to focus on what the wealthy and the elite wanted to ponder (literature, philosophy, language and history), written works in Germany focused on the practical and useful (chemistry, mechanics, mechanical engineering, optics and steel production).

The New York Times Book Review and The New York Review of Books are the heart of the United States literary establishment.

explanation.data: The text only states that New York City is the heart of the literary establishment in the US.

data: New York's importance to the literary culture of the United States comes from a combination of features that is not found anywhere else.

explanation.data: Refer to the statement, "Not only is the city the location of influential book reviews (most notably The New York Times Book Review and The New York Review of Books), influential magazines such as The New Yorker, Time, and Newsweek, and many influential book publishers, the city also boasts a large and lively population of literary writers and readers."

data: New York is a city mainly known for being the location of important book reviews, magazines, and many writers and readers.

explanation.data: The text only states that New York City is the location of influential book reviews, influential magazines, and has a population of many writers and readers. The text does not state that New York is mainly known for these characteristics.

data: If a book is not successful in New York, then it will not be successful anywhere.

explanation.data: The last sentence states: "If a novel isn't successful with the New York establishment, it rarely has a chance of entering this country's literary canon." Entering the literary canon is not a prerequisite of a book being successful.

data: The individual actions of the parts of a plasmodium, when taken collectively, move it towards things it likes, and away from things it doesn't.

explanation.data: The text states that the plasmodium flows towards things it likes, and away from things it doesn't.

data: Physarum's brain is deceptively simple.

explanation.data: The text states that the answer is deceptively simple, but we cannot apply this statement to refer to the brain of the Physarum.

data: A plasmodium can make conscious decisions about the things it does and does not like.

explanation.data: The text states that plasmodium combines all the reactions and it flows to the things that it likes and away from the thing it doesn't like, all without making a single conscious thought.

data: The UK is below average in the Nation Brands Index.

explanation.data: The texts states that UK is rated fairly highly, at 14th out of 50 (which is above average).

data: Canadians are perceived as being more honest than British people.

explanation.data: The text only states that Canada does better in terms of welcoming visitors. It does not explain how they are perceived for honesty.

data: The Netherlands is a key competitor with Britain, with regard to tourism.

explanation.data: Refer to the statement: "But some of our key competitors such as Canada, Italy, Spain, and the Netherlands do better."

data: Many people choose partners on the basis of their childhood fantasies

explanation.data: The text only states that we recoup ourselves for fantasies denied to us.

data: Stanley Spencer thought that he needed two wives.

explanation.data: Refer to the last sentence: "There are men, as Stanley Spencer said of himself, who need two complementary wives, and women who need two complementary husbands, or at least two complementary love objects."

data: Mate-selection can only be successful when both parties have similar fantasies.

explanation.data: The text only states that the result of mate-selection is a duel of rival producers because, even though both parties have the same intentions, they rarely share the same fantasies. The text does not explain if mate-selection can only be successful when both parties have similar fantasies.

data: Major Latham's Eidoloscope was unpopular because of the Latham Loop

explanation.data: The text only states that Major Woodville Latham developed an unpopular projector called Eidoloscope. The text does not explain if Eidoloscope was unpopular because of the Latham Loop.

data: The Latham Loop ensured that there was no slack film loose in the projector.

explanation.data: The text states that the addition of a slack-forming loop to the film path was to restrain the inertia of the take-up reel.

data: The Latham Loop was necessary because the take-up reel of the projector moved at an erratic speed

explanation.data: The text only states that The Latham Loop was necessary to restrain the inertia of the take-up reel of the projector. The text does not explain if the take-up reel of the projector moved at an erractic speed.

data: The median age of unauthorized immigrants is 10.4 years younger than that of legal immigrants

explanation.data: The median age for legal immigrants is 45.9 years. For unauthorized immigrants, the average age is 35.5 years. That represents a difference of 10.4 years.

data: Because they have children when they are younger, immigrant adults are more likely to have children aged over 18.

explanation.data: The text only states that immigrant adults are the parents of 23% of all children in the US aged 17 and younger.

data: U.S.-born adults are less fertile than immigrants because they are, on average, older.

explanation.data: The text only states that immigrants have a youthful age structure and higher fertility rates. The text does not explain if US-born adults are less fertile than immigrants because they are, on average, older.

data: In the United States, unauthorised immigrants are on average more likely than citizens to be parents of minors.

explanation.data: The text only states that immigrant adults are more likely than native-born adults to be parents of children younger than 18. The text does not explain if unauthorised immigrants are on average more likely than citizens to be parents of minors.

data: Most escalators use most power when they do not have passengers on.

explanation.data: The text only states that escalators offer some big opportunities for energy-saving if you can figure out how to cut power consumption during those periods when they operate without passengers on. The text does not state if most escalators use most power when they don't have passengers on.

data: All European escalators have variable-speed drives.

explanation.data: The text only states that "intermittent" or "variable-speed" escalators are popular in Europe. This does not imply that all European escalators have variable-speed drives.

data: Soon the U.S. Safety code that forbids variable-speed drives will not apply to any escalators.

explanation.data: The text states that the US safety code advises against escalators changing speed, and that a new update will lift that injunction for new machines, not for any escalator.

data: At present, compulsory safety regulations in the United States forbid energy-saving variable-speed drives being installed on escalators.

explanation.data: The national safety code in the US is a recommendation; it is not therefore compulsory.

data: Across the four studies, those in the 12th percentile scored better in terms of humour, grammar and logic than those in the 62nd.

explanation.data: The text states that those in the 12th percentile estimated themselves to be in the 62nd percentile, rather than actually scoring in the 62nd percentile.

data: As people in the bottom quartile increased their ability in the skills tested, their self-assessment of their performance improved.

explanation.data: Refer to the statement, "Paradoxically, improving the skills of participants, and thus increasing their metacognitive competence, helped themrecognize the limitations of their abilities."

data: Each of the four studies found the same thing.

explanation.data: The text only states that across four studies, the authors found that participants scoring in the bottom quartile on tests of humor, grammar, and logic grossly overestimated their test perfomance and ability. It does not explain if the studies found the same thing.

data: The amount of writing in a country is inversely proportional to the innovation in its bookselling markets.

explanation.data: The text states that the research showed much more writing going on in Germany alongside much more innovation in the bookselling market.

data: Stronger copyright laws led to the introduction of paperback books.

explanation.data: The text states that in Germany, where copyright was weak or didn't exist, cheaper paperbacks were introduced for those less well off.

data: German books tended to be on more practical subjects.

explanation.data: The text states that written works in Germany focused more on practical and useful subjects like chemistry, mechanics, mechanical engineering, optics, and steel production.
